conclusion: Determine the distance s from the launch position of the particle to point P.
The particle starts with a horizontal velocity v0 and enters the magnetic field at point P after traveling a horizontal distance x in the electric field.
The angle between the particle's velocity direction when entering the magnetic field and PQ is 60 degrees.
The time taken for the particle to travel the horizontal distance x in the electric field is t = x/v0.
The vertical component of the velocity vy is vy = -qE t.
Substituting t into the equation for vy gives vy = -qE (x/v0).
The vertical distance traveled is y = vy t = -qE (x/v0)^2.
The speed v of the particle is v = sqrt(v0^2 + vy^2).
The angle theta between the velocity vector and the horizontal is cos theta = v0/v.
Since the angle between the velocity direction and PQ is 60 degrees, we have cos 60 degrees = v0/v0 = 1, implying theta = 60 degrees.
The radius R of the circular path is related to the speed v and the magnetic field strength B by R = mv/qB.
The horizontal component of the path length is l, which is exactly the diameter of the circle formed by the path: Horizontal path length = 2R sin 60 degrees = R sqrt(3).
Since the horizontal path length is equal to l, we have l = R sqrt(3), solving for R gives R = l/sqrt(3).
The distance s is the hypotenuse of the right triangle formed by the horizontal distance x and the vertical distance y: s = sqrt(x^2 + y^2).
From earlier steps, x = R cos 60 degrees = R/2 = l/(2sqrt(3)) and y = R sin 60 degrees = R sqrt(3)/2 = l/2.
The distance from the particle's launch position to point P is l sqrt(3)/3.
